perturbation.original_text:
Any dispute, conflict or claim arising out of or in connection with this Agreement or the performance hereof shall be resolved by the Parties
through amicable negotiation, which negotiation shall commence immediately upon notice by one Party to the other of the nature of
such dispute, conflict or claim. In the event that such dispute is not resolved within thirty (30) Business Days following such notice,
either Party may upon the expiration of the such 30-day notice period submit such dispute to arbitration by the Hong Kong International
Arbitration Centre in accordance with the arbitration rules of such centre then in effect.

perturbation.explanation: Reducing the negotiation period for dispute resolution to five business days is arguably insufficient under general principles of PRC law, which emphasizes good faith negotiation and reasonable timeframes for resolving disputes. Depending on the complexity of the dispute, five days may not allow parties enough time to thoroughly investigate, negotiate, and potentially reach a settlement, potentially conflicting with legal expectations for dispute resolution processes.
perturbation.contradicted_law: PRC Contract Law - General Principles related to good faith negotiation and reasonable dispute resolution timeframes.

perturbation.original_text:
ARTICLE TEN FORCE MAJEURE

In the event that a Party's performance of this Agreement or any covenants of the Parties is directly affected by an earthquake, typhoon, flood, fire, war, computer virus, design loophole in any software tool, hacker attack on the Internet, amendment to law or policy or any other event of
force majeure which is not foreseeable or the result of which is not to be prevented or avoided, such Party shall immediately give the other Party a
notice by fax of such event and within thirty days (30) thereafter provide a detailed report thereof as well as a certification document explaining the
cause for the non-performance or delayed performance of this Agreement, which certification document shall be issued by the public notary of the
region in which the event of force majeure occurred.
perturbation.changed_text:

force majeure which is not foreseeable or the result of which is not to be prevented or avoided, such Party shall immediately give the other Party a

perturbation.explanation: Extending the period to provide a detailed report and certification document to sixty days after the initial notice of a force majeure event may violate general principles of contract law, including the duty to mitigate damages and act in a timely manner. Delaying the provision of this report could impede the other party's ability to assess the impact of the force majeure event and take appropriate steps to minimize losses, potentially conflicting with the requirements of reasonable conduct in contractual performance under PRC law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: PRC Contract Law - General Principles related to the duty to mitigate damages and timely notification and documentation in the event of force majeure.
